Label: The high father of bliss above
_description: James Ryman, a hymn of praise to God — six quatrains (aaab) with ‘Te deum laudamus’ refrain and burden: ‘Singe we alle this tyme thus / Te deum laudamus’

Label: The higher men climbeth the sorer is the fall
_description: ‘The mene ys the beste’ — three quatrains (abab) with refrain, ‘The mene ys best as semeth me’ and burden: ‘In euery state in euery degre / The mene ys the beste as semeth me’ (repeated)

Label: The holy ghost is to thee sent
_description: An Annunciation carol — six quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Hayl mary ful of grace / Moder in virginite’

Label: The knight knocked at the castle gate
Note: See Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 1545.
_description: A love song, possibly for a May disguising, by William Cornish — eight couplets with 4-line burden: “Yow and I and amyas / Amyas and yow and I / To the grenewode must we go alas / Yow and I my luff and amyas.” Includes musical notation.

Label: The last time I thee well woke
Subjects: carols, amorous;love, vicissitudes of;women, as speakers/narrators
_description: The Betrayed Maiden’s Lament — five quatrains (aaab) and burden (c): ‘I haue forsworne hit whil I life / To wake the well-ey’

Label: The man that I loved alderbest
_description: A Love Complaint, for two voices — six quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Wolde god that hyt were so / As I cowde wysshe bytuyxt vs too’

Label: The Mass is of so high dignity
Subjects: oaths, criticism of;mass;carols, of religious counsel
_description: Against swearing by the Mass — six quatrains (aaaa) and burden (bb): ‘Y concell yow both more and lasse / Beware of swerynge by the masse’

Label: The most worthy she is in town
_description: In Praise of Ivy — four quatrains (abab) with ‘Veni coronaberis’ refrain and burden: ‘Ivy chefe off treis it is / Veni coronaberis’

Label: The name of Johan well prays I may
Subjects: carols, to saints;John the Baptist, saint;hymns, to saints
_description: Carol to St. John the Baptist — five 8-line stanzas (ababcdcd) with refrain, ‘It is a name of pryce’ and 4-line burden: ‘If thou be johan I tell it the / Ryght with a good aduyce / Thou may be glad johan to be / It is a name of pryce’

Label: The nun walked on her prayer
Note: Cf. 5593, which was formerly identified with this entry.
_description: ‘Inducas inducas / In temptationibus’ — 4 macaronic quatrains (abab) with this burden
Bibliographic Ghosts: Cambridge UK, Cambridge University Library Addit. 7350, Part I: see 5593.

Label: The prophecy fulfilled is
_description: James Ryman, A Nativity carol — eight 6-line stanzas (ababcc) including refrain, ‘That nowe is borne the king of blis’ with burden (cc): ‘Right as the aungell tolde it is / That nowe is borne the king of blis’

Label: The Son of God and King of bliss
Note: First line used as refrain to 3807; four stanzas are repeated in 5258.
_description: James Ryman, a song of the Redemption — eight quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Pro salute fidelium’ and burden: ‘The sone of god is man become / Pro salute fidelium’

Label: The Son of God hath take nature
Note: In James Ryman’s songbook but not attributed to him there.
_description: ‘Te deum laudamus’, a song of the Trinity, ?by James Ryman — eight quatrains (aaab) with Te deum laudamus refrain and burden (bb): ‘Dulciter pangamus / Te deum laudamus’

Label: The Son of God our Lord Jesus
Note: In James Ryman’s songbook but not attributed to him there.
_description: ‘Te deum laudamus’, a song of the Incarnation, ?by James Ryman — three quatrains (aaab) with Te deum laudamus refrain and burden: ‘Nowe syng we thys tyme þus / Te deum laudamus’

Label: The Son of God so full of might
Note: In James Ryman’s songbook but not attributed to him there.
_description: A song of the Incarnation, ?by James Ryman — eight quatrains (abab) with refrain, ‘To saue mankynde alone’ and burden: ‘The sone of god in trone / Hath take mankynd alone’

Label: The Son of God that all hath wrought
Note: In James Ryman’s songbook but not attributed to him there
_description: A Nativity carol, ?by James Ryman — five quatrains (aaab) with ‘Te deum laudamus’ refrain, and burden: ‘Syng we alle thys tyme thus / Te deum laudamus’

Label: The Son of grace him shineth in
_description: The Son of Grace — a carol of four quatrains (abcb) and burden: ‘Al the meryere is þat place / Þe sunne of grace schynit in’

Label: The Son of the Father of heaven bliss
_description: A Christmas carol—four quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Processit ex virgine’ and burden: ‘Verbum patris hodie / Processit ex virgine’

Label: Then all your doings should here in earth
_description: Verses on Following Christ’s Word — six quatrains (aabb) and burden (cc): ‘Be mery all with one accorde / And be ye folowers of crystes worde’

Label: There is a babe born of a may
Note: For a variant cf. 20.
_description: John Audelay, an Epiphany carol — eleven quatrains (abab) and burden: ‘Nowel nowel nowel’

Label: There is a blossom sprung of a thorn
Note: For a variant see 4333.
_description: An Epiphany carol — nine quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Deo Patri sit gloria’ and burden: ‘Alleluya alleluia / Deo Patri sit gloria’

Label: There is no rose of such virtue
Subjects: carols, to Virgin Mary;carols, to Virgin Mary
_description: A song of the Virgin Mary the Rose — three 6-line stanzas (aabccb) with Latin caudae and burden: ‘Ther is no rose of swych vertu / As is the rose that bare ihesu’

Label: There is none grass that groweth in ground
Subjects: tongue, destructive power of;carols, of moral counsel
_description: A song of the ‘wikked tunge’ — five quatrains and burden: ‘Kep thi tunge thi tunge thi tunge / Thi wykyd tunge werkit me w[o]’

Label: There was a friar of the order gray / Inducas
Note: Formerly listed under similar 5426.
_description: The Friar and the Nun — eight couplets with interlinear refrain, ‘Inducas…in temptacionibus’, and burden ‘Inducas Inducas / in temptacionibus’

Label: There was some time befall a case
_description: Carol of the Passion — ten quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Jhesu fore yowre manie / Yblessid mot yowre body be’

Label: There were three wily three wily there were
Note: For a variant cf. 5111. Cf. D’Urfey (1698) XD’Urfey, Thomas. Wit and Mirth: or, Pills to Purge Melancholy. 1st ed., 4 vols, 1698-1706; 2nd ed., 6 vols, 1719-20, 2.127.
_description: Abuse of Women — four couplets and burden: ‘Herfor & therfor & therfor I came / And for to praysse this prety woman’

Label: Think man whereof thou art wrought
_description: Of the Tokens of God’s Displeasure — eight quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Man be wys & arys / & thynk on lyf þat lestenit ay’

Label: This babe to us that now is born
_description: A Christmas carol — five six-line stanzas (ababcc) with three-line refrain, ‘And thus it is / forsothe iwys / He askyth nouth but that is hys’ and burden: ‘Now may we syngyn as it is / Quod puer natus est nobis’

Label: This blessed babe that thou hast born
Note: For the earliest version (in couplets) see 3326; for other versions in quatrains see 2029 and 3424.
Subjects: carols, of the Passion;Passion;dialogues, Virgin and Christ
_description: A carol of the Passion — five six line stanzas (aaaabb) including refrain, ‘Mari moder cum and se / Thy swet son nayled on a tre’ plus burden (bb): ‘Mary moder cum and se / Thy swet son nayled on a tre’

Label: This bread giveth eternal life
Note: Stanza 2 = 2754.
_description: James Ryman, a song of the Eucharist — six quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Ete it so ye be no dede’ and burden: ‘Ete ye this brede ete ye this brede / And ete it so ye be not dede’

Label: This child is was and ay shall be
_description: James Ryman, a Nativity carol — ten 3-line stanzas (aab) with refrain (b), ‘There is a childe a heuenly childe’ and burden (bb): ‘Ther is a chielde a heuenly childe / Iborne this nyght of Marie myelde’

Label: This ender day befell a strife
_description: The Old Man Worsted — four quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Hey howe / Sely men God helpe yowe’

Label: This ender day I met a clerk
_description: Complaint of a betrayed maiden — four quatrains (aaab) and burden: A dere god qwat I am fayn / For I am madyn now gane

Label: This ender day when me was woe
_description: Fragment of a carol, probably on an amorous theme — one 3-line stanza and burden: ‘I have loued so many a day / Ligthly spedde bot better I may’

Label: This ender night / I saw a sight / A maid a cradel keep
Note: Cf. 2089 for the same burden.
_description: The Complaint of the Child Jesus to his Mother — nine six-line stanzas (aabccb) and burden: ‘Lullay my chyld & wepe no more / Slepe & be now styll / The kyng of blys this fader ys / As it was hys wyll’

Label: This ender night / I saw a sight / All in my sleep
_description: A cradle song of the Virgin Mary — in 18-line stanzas, with 7-line burden: ‘A my dere a my dere son / Seyd Mary a my dere / [lines repeated] / Kys thy moder Jhesu / Kys thi moder Jhesu / With a lawghyng chere’

Label: This flower is fair and fresh of hue
Subjects: carols, to Virgin Mary;carols, to Virgin Mary
_description: John Audelay, The Flower of Jesse, a song in praise of the Virgin Mary — seven six-line stanzas (aaaabb) and burden: ‘There is a floure spr[u]ng of a tre / The rote þerof is callid jesse / A floure of pryce / Þer is non seche in paradise’

Label: This holy time our Lord was born
Note: For a variant see 2640.
_description: A Nativity carol — one quatrain (aaab) and burden: ‘Now euery man at my request / Be glad & mery all in this fest’

Label: This is the song that ye shall hear
_description: A Nativity carol — four quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘An heuenly songe y dare wel say / Is sunge in erthe to man this day’

Label: This is the stone cut of the hill
_description: James Ryman, The Prophecy of Emmanuel — six six-line stanzas (ababbb, including a 3-line refrain, ‘Nomen eius emanuell / Scripture full welle to vs doth tell / Nomen eius emanuell’, and burden: ‘A chielde is borne with vs to dwell / Nomen eius emanuell’

Label: This night there is a child born
Note: A variant of 93.
_description: A Christmas carol — four quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Verbum caro factum est’ and burden: ‘All this tyme this songe is best / Verbum caro factum est’

Label: This other day
Note: Preceded by 257. See Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 1666.
_description: A disconsolate mistress comforted — nine six-line tail-rhyme stanzas with 2-line burden: ‘Hey nony nony nony nony no’ (repeated)

Label: This rose is railed on a rice
Subjects: carols, to Virgin Mary;carols, to Virgin Mary
_description: A macaronic song in praise of the Virgin Mary — five quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Off a rose synge we / Misterium mirabile’

Label: This time is born a child full good
_description: A Christmas carol — five quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Man be merie as bryd on berie / & al thi care let away’

Label: This voice both sharp and also shrill
_description: ‘Uenite ad iudicium’ — eight quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Uenite ad iudicium’ and two-line burden: ‘A voyce from heuen to erth shall com / Uenite ad iudicium’

Label: This wind by reason is called temptacion
Note: Formerly 3525 (alphabetized by the burden).
_description: Christ in the cold — eleven quatrains (irregular) with refrain, ‘To kype the cold wynd awaye’ and burden: ‘there blows a colde wynd todaye todaye / þe wynd blows cold todaye / cryst sufferyd his passyon for manys saluacyon / co kype the cold wynd awaye’

Label: This world is but a vanity
_description: Mane nobiscum domine — a hymn of four quatrains (aaab) with this refrain and 4-line burden: ‘O blessed lord full of pete / Mane nobiscum domine’ (repeated)

Label: This world is false I dare well say
_description: A song of the brevity of man’s life — eight quatrains (aaab) each ending with a Latin line, and Nowell burden

Label: This world lordlings I understand
Note: Stanza 8 is identical with stanza 1 of 702.
_description: A song of Doomsday — nine quatrains and burden: ‘God þat alle mytes may / Helpe vs at our ending day’

Label: This world wondereth of all thing
_description: A carol of the Incarnation — five three-line stanzas (aaa) + burden (bb): ‘VEni redemptor gencium / veni redemptor gencium’

Label: Thou art solace in all our woe
_description: James Ryman, a hymn to Christ — three quatrains (abab) including refrain, ‘Thou art welcum with us to dwell’ and burden: ‘O rex noster emanuel / Thou art welcum with us to dwell’

Label: Thou dearest disciple of Jesu Christ
Subjects: carols, of saints;John the Evangelist, saint
_description: An orison to St. John the Evangelist — five quatrains (aaab) with Latin caudae and burden: ‘Pray for vs to the trinite / Johannes christi care’

Label: Thou holy daughter of Sion
Subjects: carols, to Virgin Mary;carols, to Virgin Mary
_description: A carol to the Virgin Mary — seven quatrains (abab) and burden (cc): ‘Nouus sol de virgine / Reluxit nobis hodie’

Label: Thou sendest Thy Son from heaven city
_description: Carol of the annunciation — four 4-line stanzas including refrain, ‘Salue mater delicie’ plus burden: ‘Salue mater delicie / Almyty god in trinite’

Label: Thou sighest sore
Note: Stanza 4 same as stanza 4 of 1000.
_description: A song of the Passion, in John Grimestone’s sermon notebook — four six-line stanzas (aabccb) and burden: ‘Lu[u]eli ter of loueli eyȝe / Qui dostu me so wo / Sorful ter of sorful eyȝe / Þu brekst myn herte ato’

Label: Though thou be king of tower and town
Note: Stanza 4 is almost identical with stanza 1 of 3344.
_description: Verses urging Man to make Amends — five quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘But if þou wylt amendis make’ and burden: ‘Synful man for godis sake / I rede þat þou amendis make’

Label: Three kings on the twelfth day
_description: James Ryman, an Epiphany carol — eight macaronic six-line stanzas (ababcc) with refrain, ‘Ex illibata virgine’ and burden: ‘Ortus est sol iusticie / Ex illibata virgine’

Label: Thus it is said in prophecy
_description: James Ryman, a Nativity carol — six 5-line stanzas (aaaab) including refrain, ‘Now in this fest this holy fest’ and 4-line burden (bbbb): ‘Now in this fest this holy fest / Nunc puer nobis natus est (repeated) / Et puer nobis datus est’

Label: Thus said Mary of great honor
_description: James Ryman, a hymn on the Magnificat — eight quatrains (abab) and burden (cc): ‘Vnto marie he that loue hath / To here synge he Magnificat’

Label: Thus to her said an angel tho
_description: James Ryman, a song of the Annunciation — five quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Mary hath borne alone / The sonne of god in trone’

Label: Thy creatures terrestrial
_description: James Ryman, a macaronic hymn to God the Father, based on the Te Deum — eight quatrains with refrain, ‘Te deum verumque laudamus’ and burden: ‘Te patrem nostrum inuocamus / Te deum verumque laudamus’

Label: Thy tongue is made of flesh and blood
Subjects: carols, of moral counsel;tongue, advice concerning use of
_description: A song of keeping the tongue — five quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Man bewar bewar bewar / & kepe the þat þou haue no car’

Label: Tidings I bring for you for to tell
_description: A Boar’s Head song — two irregular 9-line stanzas (aaabccddb)

Label: Tidings true there become new
_description: A song of the Annunciation — 4 stanzas, 1st and last with 6 lines (abbccc and abcbdd), middle two with 8 lines (abcbdbeb) plus burden (ff): ‘Newell newell newell newell / This ys þe salutacion of Gabryell’

Label: Tidings true told there is true
_description: A Christmas carol — two quatrains (abba) with refrain, ‘Blessed be Jhesu’ and 4-line burden: ‘Tydynges trew ther buthe come newe / Blessed be Jhesu’ (repeated)

Label: Til home shall Willikin this joly gentle sheep
_description: Willikin’s Return, a political carol in support of Henry VI — four 3-line stanzas (aab) with refrain, ‘Therfore let vs all syng nowell’ and burden: ‘Nowell nowell nowell nowell / & cryst saue mery Y[n]glon[d] & sped yt well’

Label: To Christ Jesu that Lord and King
Subjects: carols, of the Trinity;Christ, burial and resurrection
_description: James Ryman, a song of the Passion and Resurrection — five quatrains (aaab) with ‘Te deum’ refrain and burden: ‘Te patrem inuocamus / Te deumque laudamus’

Label: To the shepherds keeping their fold
_description: James Ryman, a Nativity carol — seven quatrains (aaab) and burden (cc): ‘In terra pax hominibus / Quia natus est dominus’

Label: To thee now Christs dear darling
Subjects: carols, to saints;John the Evangelist, saint
_description: Hymn to St. John the Evangelist — four quatrains (abac) including refrain, ‘Amice Christi Iohannes’, plus burden(dc): ‘Pray for vs to the prince of peace / Amice Crysty Iohannes’

Label: To this rose angel Gabriel
_description: James Ryman, a carol of the Annunciation — six quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘The whiche floure is moos pure & bright’ and burden: ‘A roose hath borne a lilly white / The whiche floure is moos pure & bright’

Label: To unpraise women it were a shame
_description: In praise of women — three quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘I am as lyght as any roe / To preyse wemen wher that I goo’

Label: Truth it is full securely
_description: The Visit of the Magi — 96 lines in cross-rhymes quatrains with an introductory refrain, ‘The sterre shoon boþe nyȝt & day’

Label: Under a tree
_description: The Virgin Mary’s song of the Miraculous Conception — six 6-line stanzas (aabccb) and burden: ‘Nowel nowel nowel / Syng we with myrth / Cryst is come wel / With vs to sewell / By hys most noble byrth’

Label: Upon a lady fair and bright
Note: Burden same as 5272.
Subjects: carols, to Virgin Mary;carols, to Virgin Mary
_description: A song of the Virgin Mary — four five-line stanzas (ababc) including refrain, ‘Newell’ or ‘Nowell’ plus burden (cc): ‘Newell newell newell newell / I thank a maydyn euery dele’

Label: Upon a morning of May
_description: The beginning of a chanson d’aventure of a man in black — three 6-line tail-rhyme stanzas and burden: ‘Wep no more ffor me swet hart / Wepe no more for me / As scharpe as a dart hathe perysht my hart / That ye shod morne for me’

Label: Upon a night an angel bright
_description: James Ryman, a macaronic song of the Nativity — eight 6-line stanzas (ababcc) with ‘Nunc natus est altissimus’ refrain and burden: ‘Angelus inquit pastoribus / Nunc natus est altissimus’

Label: Upon the cross nailed was I for thee
Subjects: Christ, complaint to man;carols, of Christ’s pleading;envoys;dialogues, Christ and man
_description: John Lydgate, ‘Why artow froward sith I am mercyable?’ — five 8-line stanzas, including one-stanza envoy and one-stanza ‘oracio’ (formerly 1967.5) and refrain ‘Why artow froward sith I am mercyable?’
Title(s): Why artow froward sith I am mercyable? (Lydgate)

Label: We bearen about none cats skins
_description: A Pedlar’s carol (with double entendre) — four quatrains (abab) and burden: ‘We ben chapmen lyȝt of fote / þe fowle weyis for to fle’

Label: Welcome be this blessed feast
_description: A song of the Trinity — five quatrains (abab) and burden: ‘O meruelous & blessed natiuite / Off goddes sone in diuinite’

Label: Welcome be Thou heaven king
_description: A Christmas carol — five quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Welcum yole for euer & ay’ and burden: ‘Welcum yole in glod aray / In worchip of the holeday’

Label: Wheat is both seemly and soot
_description: In praise of Wheat — six quatrains with refrain, ‘So blyssid be the qwete flour’ and burden: ‘Of alle the spyces þat I knowe / Blyssid be the qwete flour’

Label: When Alleluia is aloft
Note: A burden may be lacking, or possibly acephalous. No MS extant.
Subjects: complaints;carols, of Lent;seasons, of church year
_description: The Complaint of Lent — four quatrains

Label: When Christ was born an angel bright
_description: James Ryman, a Christmas carol — eight quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Gloria in altissimis / For nowe is borne the king of blis’

Label: When Christ was born of Mary free
_description: A Christmas carol — four quatrains and burden: ‘Christo paremus cantica / In excelsis gloria’

Label: When false Judas Her Son had sold
Subjects: carols, of the Passion;laments;Virgin Mary, lament of
_description: James Ryman, a lament of the Virgin Mary — five quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Mary myelde made grete mone / For her dere sonne alone’

Label: When God was born of Mary free
_description: A carol for Innocents’ Day — two macaronic 5-line stanzas and 4-line Latin burden: ‘Psallite gaudentes / Infantum festa colentes’ (repeated)

Label: When I have in my purse enough
_description: ‘Gramersy myn owyn purs’ — four quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Syng we alle & sey we thus / Gramersy myn owyn purs’

Label: When I went beyond the sea
_description: Fare Far and Have Little — five quatrains and burden: ‘Hos is to hoth at hom / Ryd out it wol agon’

Label: When Jesu Christ baptized was
_description: An Epiphany carol — four quatrains (aaab) including refrain, ‘Hic est filius meus dilectus ipsum audite,’ plus burden (bb): ‘Ihesus autem hodie / Egressus est de virgine’

Label: When lordship is lost and lusty looking withall
Note: Cf. 3927 for a related work.
Subjects: carols, of religious counsel;evils of the time
_description: ‘Spes mea in deo est’ — a song of three quatrains (aaab) with this refrain and 2-line burden: ‘Spes mea in deo est’ (repeated)

Label: When nettles in winter bring forth roses red
Note: Cf. Edinburgh, National Library of Scotland, Advocates’ 1.1.6 [Bannatyne MS], f. 115v, pr. Ritchie (1928) XRitchie, W. Tod. The Bannatyne Manuscript. 4 parts in 4 vols. Scottish Text Society 3rd ser. 5 (1928); n.s. 22 (1928); n.s. 23 (1930); n.s. 26 (1934) Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1928-34; ed. by Ritchie et al, 3.66; f. 266 pr. Ritchie (1928) XRitchie, W. Tod. The Bannatyne Manuscript. 4 parts in 4 vols. Scottish Text Society 3rd ser. 5 (1928); n.s. 22 (1928); n.s. 23 (1930); n.s. 26 (1934) Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1928-34; ed. by Ritchie et al, 4.42; f. 266v pr. Ritchie (1928) XRitchie, W. Tod. The Bannatyne Manuscript. 4 parts in 4 vols. Scottish Text Society 3rd ser. 5 (1928); n.s. 22 (1928); n.s. 23 (1930); n.s. 26 (1934) Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1928-34; ed. by Ritchie et al, 4.44. Cf. 6277. For a later satirical religious adaptation see 6483. Cf. Dean-Smith and Nicol (1943) XMargaret [Nicol] Dean-Smith, and E. J. Nicol. “’The Dancing Master’: 1651-1728.” Journal of the English Folk Dance and Song Society 4.4 (Dec., 1943): 131-145, 132.
Subjects: women, satire directed against;carols, of women;impossibilities
_description: When to trust women — seven stanzas rhyme royal including refrain, ‘Than put in a woman your trust & confidence’

Label: When no thing was but God alone
Note: The first three lines and burden are also found in 6386.
_description: A song of the mysteries of God’s works — six 7-line stanzas (aaabbbb) with refrain, ‘What is why /To frayne why I hold it but foly / It is non other sertenly / But virtus verbi domini’ and burden: ‘Why why what is this whi / But virtus verbi domini’

Label: When nothing was but God alone
Note: The first three lines, and first and third lines of burden, duplicate 6385.
_description: On the Power of God’s Word — nine 3-line stanzas (aaa) and burden: ‘Why why what ys this why / Hit ys non nodyre sekurely / But werttus wereby domini’

Label: When Saint Stephen was at Jerusalem
_description: A carol for St. Stephen’s Day — five quatrains with refrain element, ‘…lapidauerunt stephanum’ and burden: ‘Nowe syng we both all & sum / Lapidauerunt stephanum’

Label: When that my sweet son was thirty winter old
Subjects: carols, of the Passion;women, as speakers/narrators
_description: A song of the Passion by the Virgin Mary — five monorhyming quatrains and burden: ‘O my harte is woo mary she sayd so / For to se my dere son dye & sonnes haue I no mo’

Label: Where be ye
Note: Possibly a modified carol in four stanzas and introductory burden: ‘No comfortyng but yow’. See Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 2037.
_description: ‘No comfortyng but yow’ — five 6-line tail-rhyme stanzas

Label: Whereas Adam caused by sin
_description: A Nativity carol — three 6-line stanzas (ababcc) and burden: ‘Tydynges tydynges that be trwe / Sorowe ys paste and joye dothe renwe’

Label: Wherefore should I hang up my bow
Note: For a companion piece, see 2176. See Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 1929.
_description: A ‘jolly forester:’ the lover still active — 4 stanzas in long-line couplets and 6-line burden: ‘I am a joly foster / I am a joly foster / And haue ben many a day / & foster will I be styll / For shote ryght well I may / For shot ryght well I may.’ Includes musical notation.

Label: While I was young and had courage
Note: For a very similar piece see 5712.
_description: A song of old age — three quatrains (aaab) with Latin caudae and 4-line burden: ‘The beste song as hit semeth me / Peccantem me cotidie’ (repeated)

Label: While men have their barns full
_description: The carol of Jak Rekles — four quatrains (aaab) and burden: ‘Ay ay be þis day / ȝ wyll mak mery qwyll y may’

Label: Whilom I present was with my sovereign
_description: The Complaint of one banished — eight 8-line stanzas (aabbcddc) and burden: ‘For pencynesse & gret distresse / I am full woo / Destitute frome al refute / Alone I goo’

Label: Why sittest thou so singing thinkest thou nothing
_description: Verses reminding reader to remember the Pains of Purgatory — six stanzas of four monorhyming lines plus monorhyming refrain of increasing length, each ending ‘Thou schalt aby / This worlde defygh’ and burden: ‘Peas I hier a voyce saith man thou shalt dye / Remembre the paynes of purgatorie’

Label: With favor in her face far passing my Reason
Subjects: Virgin Mary, lament of;carols, of the Passion
_description: A lament of the Virgin Mary over her Son — four 9-line stanzas (aaaabbbcc) with refrain ‘Who can not wepe come lerne of me’ and a 4-line burden: ‘Sodenly afraide / Half wakyng half slepyng / And gretly dismayde / A wooman sate weepyng’

Label: With pacience thou has us fed
_description: Farewell to Advent — sixteen quatrains (aaab) with refrain, ‘Farewele fro vs bothe alle and sume’ (except last stanza, ‘In ortu regis omnium’) and burden: ‘Farewele aduent cristemas is cum / Farewele fro vs bothe alle and sume’.

Label: With pity moved I am constrained
Subjects: tongue, destructive power of;carols, of moral counsel
_description: A song of the Tongue, man’s enemy — five 5-line stanzas (ababb) and burden: ‘Off al the enmys þat i can fynd / The tong is most enmy to mankynd.’

Label: Women beth both good and sheen
Note: For similar pieces see 2512 and 4826.
Subjects: women, praise of;carols, of women;Virgin Mary, praise of
_description: A song in praise of women — five quatrains with refrain, ‘Witnesse on Marie’, and burden: ‘Wymmen beth bothe goude & truwe / Wytnesse on marie’

Label: Worship be the birth of thee
_description: A macaronic hymn of the Nativity — six quatrains with refrain, Ave domina and burden: Ave domina / Celi regina

Label: Worship of virtue is the meed
_description: Carol to St. George—three quatrains and burden: ‘Enfors we vs withall our myght / To loue seynt georg owr lady knyght’

Label: X for Christs him self was dight
Note: Cf. 1722, stanza 2, lines 5-6 and stanza 4, which Greene (1977) XGreene, Richard Leighton. The Early English Carols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon, 1977 (see also Greene (1935) XGreene, Richard Leighton. The Early English Carols. Oxford: Clarendon, 1935; 2nd ed., rev., Oxford: Clarendon, 1977), 361 identifies as the likely source for this poem.
_description: A song of X and M and I and E — five quatrains and burden: ‘Of X & M & oþer too / Of I & E I syng all so’

Label: Ye been my father by creation
_description: Song of the Virgin Mary to the Christ Child—five quatrains including refrain, ‘My owyn dyre sone lullay’, and burden: ‘Lullay my fader lullay my brother / Myn owyn dyre sone lullay‘.

Label: Young men I rede that ye beware
Note: See Utley (1944) XUtley, Francis Lee. The Crooked Rib. Ohio State Contributions in Language and Literature 10. Columbus, OH: Ohio State UP, 1944. 400.
_description: Beware of a shrewish wife — three quatrains and burden: ‘In soro & car he led hys lyfe / Þat haue a schrow ontyll is wyfe’

Label: Young men I warn you everyone
_description: Verses against marrying elderly women — five quatrains with refrain, ‘I dar not seyȝ quan che seȝt pes’ and burden: ‘How hey it is not les / I dar not seyȝ quan che seȝt pes’

Label: Young men that bearen them so gay
_description: A song of Doomsday — five quatrains and burden: Gay gay to be gay / I holde it but a vanite

Label: Your light grievance shall not me constrain
_description: A song to his uncertain mistress — four monorhyming quatrains (same rhyme throughout) with refrain and burden: ‘How shold Y plece a creature uncerteyne’

Label: Youth lust reaches or manhood
_description: An Exhortation to God’s Service — twelve monorhyming quatrains and burden: ‘When all ys don and all ys sayd / God must be known seruyd & obeid’

Label: A Christian priest was called Carpus
_description: The story of Carpus in the Northern Homily Cycle — in couplets

Label: At the beginning of the charterhouse God did show
_description: The Founding of the Carthusian Order — twenty-nine couplets

Label: On cliff that castle so knettered
_description: An alliterative poem (with some phrases from Sir Gawain and the Green Knight) describing a castle, the approach of summer, and love-making, perhaps by Humfrey Newton — 53 alliterative lines in rhyming quatrains

Label: All that willen of wisdom lere / Listen to me and ye shall hear
Subjects: legends;dialogues;catechisms, on science and biblical lore
_description: The ‘Legend of Ipotis’ — in couplets

Label: Father and Son and Holy Ghost / As Thou art Lord of mights most
Note: For the abridged version see 2147; see also Boccus and Sydrake, c. 1532 (STC 3186-7), and cf. Bülbring (1902) XBülbring, Karl Daniel. “Sidrac in England.” Beiträge zur romanischen und englisch Philologie: Festgabe für Wendelin Foerster. Hallem a.d.S., 1902: 442-78.
Subjects: catechisms, scientific and biblical lore;instructional verse;doctrine, religious;translations
_description: Sydrac and Boctus (longer version), translated from the French by Hugh of Campeden — about 22,250 lines in couplets
Bibliographic Ghosts: Princeton, Princeton University Library Taylor Medieval 3 [olim Morent’s Court, Kent, Meyerstein, Sotheby’s 17 Dec. 1952, lot 466]: see 3465

Label: Men may find in old books
Note: For the longer version cf. 1276.
Subjects: dialogues;didactic verse;doctrine, religious;catechisms, scientific and biblical lore
_description: Sydrac and Boctus, the didactic dialogue on morals and doctrines, with 1084 questions — abridged version. Translated by Hugh Campeden from the French (cf. Bodl. SC 2451); Sydrach (1486) XSydrach, Philosophe. La fontaine de toutes sciences. Paris: [Pierre Levet] for Antoine Vérard [and Nicole Gilles], 20 Feb. 1486/87

Label: This is the book that I thee take
_description: ‘Rhasis Cestrensis de 12 aquis’ with a prefatory Dialogue between Rhasis and his son Merlin — the opus (‘Doctrina Patris ad Merlinum’) in twenty paragraphs in couplets
Title(s): ‘Doctrina Patris ad Merlinum’; ‘Rhasis Cestrensis de 12 aquis’

Label: Courteous Caton
_description: On Cato, pagan yet Christian — five tail-rhyme stanzas of 6 short lines

Label: I have twelve oxen that be fair and brown
Note: Considered as an English englyn, cf. Journal of the English Folk Dance and Song Society 4, 130.
_description: A poem about oxen, possibly erotic — four couplets and two-line refrain

Label: As I stood in a royal hall
_description: Ever say Well or hold Thee Still — ten 8-line stanzas

Label: Mother of mercy shield him from th’orrible fiend
_description: Probable epitaph of William Caxton: ‘Bring hym to lyff eternall that neuyr hath ynd’ — one couplet

Label: Pray for the souls of John Caxton and of Joane
Subjects: epitaphs;inscriptions;Caxton, John and Joane, of Canterbury
_description: Epitaph — 12 lines

Label: Cecelia is as much to say
_description: Osbern Bokenham, Life of St Cecilia — in various verse forms

Label: Jesu Christ full of pity
_description: Life of St. Cecilia, in the ‘expanded’ Northern Homily Cycle

Label: Saint Cecilia of noble kind I-bore was at Rome
_description: Life of St. Cecilia in the South English Legendary — couplets

Label: To say something is mine entent
_description: Life of St. Cecilia, in the Scottish Legendary

Label: All of a story I will you read
_description: ‘þe lyfe of Celestyn’ — 147 5-line stanzas

Label: Saint Chad the good man was born of England
_description: Life of St. Chad in the South English Legendary — couplets

Label: My lords of Chalker please you to hear
_description: ‘To the lordis of the kingis chalker’, by William Dunbar — four 5-line stanzas
Title(s): ‘To the lordis of the kingis chalker’

Label: Jesu that suffered bitter passion and pain
_description: Epitaph, A.D. 1487, for John Chamberleyn and his wives — eight lines

Label: Agwillare habeth stan diff yn lantern this tale me [t]old
Note: Cf. Ficker (1936) XFicker, Rudolf von. “Agwillare, A Piece of Late Gothic Minstrelsy.” Musical Quarterly 22 (1936): 131-9, 131-7.
_description: Fragment of a chanson (or ballade) apparently in English, misunderstood by a foreign scribe

Label: As I came by a forest side
_description: ‘Do for þi selfe wyle þat þu art here’ — nine 8-line stanzas
Title(s): ‘Do for þi selfe wyle þat þu art here’

Label: As I fared in a frith
Subjects: wealth, wise use of;chansons d’aventure;dream poems
_description: ‘In þi most welth wisely be ware’ — eleven 8-line stanzas
Title(s): ‘In þi most welth wisely be ware’

Label: As I walked upon a day / To take the air of field & flower
Note: Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler .
_description: Give me License to live in Ease — eleven 12-line stanzas with refrain phrase ‘to lyue in ease.’

Label: I heard an harping on a hill as I lay under lind
_description: A chanson d’aventure song of the Passion with symbolic letters — six 6-line stanzas with ‘O and I’ refrain

Label: In a garden underneath a tree
_description: A chanson d’aventure of the unhappy lover — six 6-line tail-rhyme stanzas and a 2-line refrain: ‘This nyghtes rest’.

Label: In a seemly summers tide
_description: ‘Mesure is best of all thynge’ — three 8-line stanzas and an Envoy of four lines

Label: In May when every heart is light
Subjects: Edward IV, death of;laments;chansons d’aventure;May, songs of
_description: ‘The lame[ntacioun] of ladyes for the death of King Edward the iiijth’ — originally five stanzas rhyme royal, but left-hand portion of page torn away leaving fragmentary first stanza only
Title(s): ‘The lame[ntacioun] of ladyes for the death of King Edward the iiijth’

Label: In the forest of noyous heaviness
_description: A meeting with Venus, translated from the French of Charles d’Orléans (Champollion-Figeac (1842) XChampollion-Figeac, Aime. Les Poesies du duc Charles d’Orleans. Paris, 1842, 123) — three 8-line stanzas and 5-line Envoy

Label: In the season of huge mortality
Note: Preceded by 5100 and 6469.
_description: ‘A disputacion betwyx þe body and wormes’ — thirty-one stanzas rhyme royal
Title(s): ‘A disputacion betwyx þe body and wormes’

Label: In wilderness / There found I Bess
_description: A betrayed maiden, with a chanson d’aventure opening — eight 6-line tail-rhyme stanzas

Label: Now fell me when this Jubilee thus was made
_description: Charles d’Orléans, a love sequence, consisting of chanson d’aventure adventures of the poet in the realm of Love — 94 stanzas rhyme royal with inserted ‘bill of complaynt’ of seven 8-line stanzas

Label: This ender day / As I went to play
_description: In the manner of a chanson d’aventure — 32 lines in eight rhymed quatrains

Label: This ender night / When stars shone bright
Subjects: chansons d’aventure;dialogues, Christ and man;Christ, love to sinners
_description: A dialogue between Christ and the Sinner, with chamson d’aventure opening — two six-line tail-rhyme stanzas and nineteen couplets

Label: Upon a summer Sunday see I the sun
_description: ’Somer Soneday’ — 133 lines in 13-line stanzas alternating with ‘Versus’ of 8 short lines

Label: Charity is bright of word
Note: Caritas paciens est, beningna est, etc. written to right.
_description: The Sixteen Points of Charity — eight couplets paraphrasing I Cor.13:4-8 in John Grimestone’s sermon notes

Label: Charity is chased all about
Note: Preceeded by 3276, and followed by 4350, 140.
_description: The absence of charity — two couplets in a Latin sermon by Friar Nicholas Philipp

Label: I am he that will not flee
_description: English couplet translating ‘Ego sum illy quy non youlte fugere da mychi bacoulum par carytatye’

Label: Love come out fro heaven
_description: The seven gifts of the Holy Spirit to teach men to live in charity, attributed to ‘Breche’ — eighteen three-line stanzas (aab) plus three-line burden (ccb): ‘Sanctus sanctus sanctus / God almyȝte graunte ovs / Loue & charite & charite’

Label: Man among thy mirths have in mind
Note: For another metrical version, see 970
_description: The XVI Points of Charity — fourteen 8-line stanzas

Label: These make perfect charity after Pauls epistle
Note: Probably copied from Here begynneth a lytyll treatyse schortely compyled and called ars moriendi that is to saye the craft for to deye for the helthe of mannes sowle, [Westminster: W. Caxton, 1491] ; facs. Nicholson (1891) XNicholson, Edward Williams Byron. Ars moriendi. Facsimile of Caxton, Ars Moriendi, 1491. London: Quaritch, 1891; rpr. Blades (1869) XBlades, William. Ars moriendi; printed by William Caxton. 1491; repr. Westminster, 1869; or from Betson, Thomas, Here begynneth a ryght profytable treatyse co[m]pendiously drawen out of many [and] dyuers wrytynges of holy men, to dyspose men to be vertuously occupyed in theyr myndes [and] prayers, [Westminster: Wynkyn de Worde, 1500] .
_description: ‘The XV degrees of charite’ — two eight-line stanzas

Label: Whoso would bethink him well
_description: ‘Charite is no lengor Cheere’ — fourteen 8-line stanzas with this refrain

Label: All worthy men that loves to hear
_description: The Sege of Melayne, a Charlemagne Romance — in 12-line stanzas

Label: He ate bread but a quantity
Note: Previously misidentified as fragments of 2763.
_description: Metrical exemplum concerning Charlemagne and Theobaldus of Champagne, similar to versions found in ‘Jacob’s Well’ and the ‘Alphabet of Tale’

Label: Of Charles the Great and emperor most Christian
_description: Epitaph of Charlemagne, in Part VI of Fabyan’s Chronicle, Part VI, cap. 155 — one couplet

Label: Behold this great Prince Edward the Second
Note: Ringler Jr. (1992) XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 25.
Subjects: princes, fall of;political verse;Edward II, death of;Richard II;Thomas, Duke of Gloucester;Louis, duke of Orleans;Robert de Vere, duke of Ireland (1386-88);John, Duke of Burgundy;Charles VII, King of France
Subjects_Primary: princes;political verse;Edward II;Richard II;Thomas;Louis;Robert de Vere;John;Charles VII
_description: John Lydgate, ‘Of the Sodein Fal of Princes in oure Dayes’ — seven stanzas rhyme royal
Title(s): ‘Of the Sodein Fal of Princes in oure Dayes’

Label: All from evil thing
_description: A prayer or charm for protection against evil, introducing ‘In nomine patris’ — one quatrain

Label: As thou Lord diddest stop and stay
_description: ‘A charm agaynst thy enemyes’ — eleven couplets

Label: As wisely as Christ was
_description: A charm based on the wisdom of Christ — seven lines in couplets

Label: Before the gate of Galilee
_description: Charm for sore teeth — six couplets

Label: Christ that was in Bethlehem born
Note: Cf. 1023, 1622, and 3188; edition for which MS not identified [not Sloane 88] Wright and Halliwell-Phillipps (1845) XThomas Wright, and James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps. Reliquiae Antiquae. 2 vols. London: Smith, 1845, 1.315.
_description: A charm to staunch blood — varying number of lines and rhyme
Bibliographic Ghosts: Boston, MA, Boston Public Library med. 124 (1546) [olim Sowter, Sotheby Sale, May 20, 1947, Lot 371; olim Le Neve, Horae], ff. 109v-110v: French verse.

Label: Christ was done on a tree
_description: A charm against ‘heuyll’ by the wounds of Christ — six lines

Label: Christ was of the virgin Mary born
_description: A charm for staunching blood — one quatrain

Label: Foul fiend away thou flee
_description: St Katherine’s charm for banishing despair (in Gesta Romanorum) — four lines

Label: From all manner thieves and untrue men
_description: A charm against thieves — twelve couplets and two Latin quatrains

Label: God and saint Trinity / As I believe on thee
Note: Followed by 2155.
_description: A prayer and conjuration against robbers — four couplets

Label: God was bore God was well bore
_description: ‘For þe falyon rankelyng fester’ — a charm of six lines

Label: God was I-bore in Bethlehem
_description: Charm against thieves — roughly four couplets, then a prose passage, then two couplets

Label: God was I-born in Bedlam / I-born he was to Jerusalem
_description: A charm against wolves and thieves (perhaps originally addressed to Woden) — in rough couplets

Label: Help cross fairest of timbers three
_description: A universal charm by the Holy Rood — eight lines (ababacac)

Label: Here I am and forth I must
_description: A charm against enemies — nine lines

Label: I beseech the Holy Ghost this place that here is set
_description: Charm/prayer against thieves — four lines

Label: I betake the Holy Ghost this place here I-set
_description: A charm against thieves — 16 lines, in couplets

Label: I command all the rattons that are here about
_description: Charm against Rats — twenty-one irregular lines

Label: I conjure the loathly beast with that ilk spear
Note: Followed by 5800.
_description: A charm for the tooth-ache — 14 lines, 5 couplets plus 4 unrhymed lines

Label: I conjure the wound belive
_description: A charm against a wound — fourteen lines in couplets
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, British Library Addit. 19674

Label: I conjure them in the name of the father
Note: Following 1548.
_description: A charm against thieves — in couplets
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, Bodleian Library Laud misc. 685 (SC 817), f. 205: possibly confused with 1462.

Label: If any thieves come nigh
_description: Prayer and conjuration against thieves — four couplets plus two line Latin conjuration

Label: Job down the hill he set
Note: For three related prose versions, see Gray (1974) XGray, Douglas. “Notes on Some Middle English Charms.” In Chaucer and Middle English Studies in Honour of Rossell Hope Robbins. Beryl Rowland London: Allen and Unwin, 1974, 64-5. Cf. 2952.
_description: A charm for chancre, with Latin instructions for its use — four lines

Label: Job in a dunghill lay
_description: Charm to rid worms — four roughly-rhyming couplets

Label: Lord God in Trinity / Father and Son and Holy Ghost
Note: Cf. 6653 and a variant, 420.
_description: ‘For metyng of theues saie thou this charm’ — twelve couplets
Title(s): For metyng of theues saie thou this charm

Label: On boughs of tree of great might
_description: A verse charm, Jesus on the cross — one six-line stanza in couplets

Label: Our Lord Jesu Christ
_description: Charm for sprained or dislocated wrists or ankles — rough couplets and a triplet

Label: Peters brother where liest all night
_description: The White Benedictus, a spell — eighteen irregular lines

Label: Saint George our Lady knight
_description: A charm against nightmare — nine lines

Label: Saint Nycasie had a pock small
_description: Charm for the pox — three couplets

Label: Some send elves
_description: Six lines on Wade, inserted in a Latin sermon on humility — two roughly-rhyming triplets

Label: Staunch blood staunch blood
_description: A charm to stop bleeding — four short lines

Label: The man that the hare I-met
_description: Burlesque charm by the names of a hare — introduction and conclusion of five couplets each, with forty-four lines of text of the names of the hare

Label: Three good brothers are ye
Note: Preceded by 2153.
_description: A Charm against Toothache — twenty-one couplets

Label: To the Holy Ghost my goods I bequeath
_description: A charm against thieves — seventeen lines, possibly in ten-line stanzas

Label: Wenne Wenne Wenchichenne
_description: A Charm — thirteen alliterative lines

Label: What manner of evil thou be in Gods name I conjure thee
_description: ‘Medicina pro morbo caduco et le fevre’ — seven couplets
Title(s): ‘Medicina pro morbo caduco et le fevre’

Label: Whoso will this orison say
_description: A charm against thieves — ten couplets

Label: I Edward King
_description: ‘Charta Sancti Edwardi Regis de concessione ballivae suae’ — twenty-two lines
Title(s): ‘Charta Sancti Edwardi Regis de concessione ballivae suae’

Label: I John of Gaunt
_description: A [?spurious] grant by John of Gaunt, granting the manors of Sutton and Potton to Sir Roger Burgoyne and his heirs — three doggerel couplets

Label: Jesu king of heaven and hell / Man and woman I will thee tell
Note: For the B and C Texts see 6650 and 1913.
_description: The ‘Long Charter’ of Christ (A Text) — 234 lines in couplets

Label: Jesu of Nazareth the king of Jews
Note: For other texts of the Charter of Christ see 1913, 2859, 6650, 6768, 6769.
_description: ‘Magna carta libertatis & remissionis generalis’ — ten quatrains (abab)
Title(s): Magna carta libertatis & remissionis generalis; Charter of Christ

Label: Knowen all men that are and shall been
_description: ’Carta Dei’ (one form of the ‘Charter of Christ’) — forty-two lines in couplets

Label: Knoweth that beth and shall be
_description: Inscription over the entrance to Cowling Castle, near Rochester, Kent (late fourteenth century) — four lines

Label: Whoso will over read this book
Note: For the A Text see 2859; for the C Text see 1913.
_description: The ‘Long Charter of Christ’ (B text) — 414 lines in couplets

Label: Wittes all that be here
_description: Christ’s Will and Testament, a version of the ‘Short’ Charter of Christ — in couplets

Label: Witteth now all that been here
_description: The ‘Short Charter of Christ’ — couplets

Label: Almighty God maker of all
_description: The Wright’s Chaste Wife — 672 lines in 6-line stanzas

Label: Lo here this noble poet of Britain
_description: Tribute to Geoffrey Chaucer — rhyme royal

Label: Master Geoffrey Chaucer that now lieth in grave
_description: Balade in praise of Chaucer — one stanza rhyme royal: lines II. 1628-34 from Lydgate’s Life of Our Lady (4080). See Wellesley (2018) XWellesley, Mary. “John Lydgate’s Life of our Lady: Form and Transmission.” Diss. University College, London, 2018. [https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/id/eprint/10054615/1/Wellesley_10054615_thesis.pdf]
